Project Number: 51390-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2018 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Research on Qinghai’s 
Integration into Belt and Road Tourism
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support Qinghai Province of the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) in formulating sustainable regional tourism strategies to be 
integrated into the Belt and Road Initiative’s economic opportunities that would be available within 
the PRC by capitalizing on the province’s unique character, while preserving its unique ecological 
and cultural assets. 
 
2.  The Government of the PRC has requested the TA from the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) as part of its effort to support the lesser-developed northwestern regions of the country to 
promote green and inclusive economic growth.1 Following a mission on 20 October 2018, ADB 
and the executing and implementing agencies for the project reached an understanding on the 
TA  objectives,  scope,  implementation  arrangements,  costs,  and  terms  of  reference  for 
consultants.2 The TA is included in ADB’s country operations business plan, 2018–2020 for the 
PRC.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The economic impact of travel and tourism is growing globally. The direct and indirect 
contribution  of  travel  and  tourism  to  the  PRC’s  gross  domestic  product  in  2017  was 
$1,349.3 billion, or 11% of the total gross domestic product, and this is forecast to grow at 6.6% 
per year by 2028. It was also estimated that about 10.3% of the PRC employment was directly or 
indirectly supported by travel and tourism in 2017, and this is forecast to grow at 3.5% per year 
between  2018  and  2028.4 Tourism  contributes  to  economic  growth  and  job  creation,  and 
increasingly also to environmental protection and cultural preservation through better planning, 
management, and protection of ecology and local culture.5 
 
4.  Qinghai is on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau and at the heart of the ancient Silk Road routes, 
along with other northwestern provinces and regions such as Gansu, Ningxia, Shaanxi, and 
Xinjiang. It has a land area of about 720,000 square kilometers with an average altitude of more 
than 3,000 meters. Qinghai is one of the least-densely populated regions in the PRC with about 
6 million inhabitants, of whom 46.9% live in rural areas. About 47.7% of the population belongs 
to more than 50 ethnic minorities, whose origins are often related to cultures outside of Qinghai. 
The eastern part of the province is on a highland with altitudes ranging from 1,800 to 2,700 meters, 
and about 65% of the Qinghai population is concentrated in Xining City, the provincial capital, and 
Haidong City. The rest is dispersed in the remaining 97% of the area administered by six 
autonomous prefectures. In the northwestern part of the province lies Qaidam Basin, a barren 
desert with salt lakes and rich oil, coal, and mineral resources. The southern part of the province 
includes high-altitude grasslands and mountains more than 6,000 meters above sea level. 
Qinghai is home to rare and unique wildlife and important wetland, grasslands, and forests. Three 
of Asia’s major rivers originate here: the Mekong River, Yangtze River, and Yellow River. 
 
                                                
1  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila; and ADB. 2016. Country Partnership Strategy: Transforming Partnership: People’s Republic of China and 
Asian Development Bank, 2016–2020. Manila.  
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 26 November 2018. 
3  ADB. 2018. Country Operations Business Plan: People’s Republic of China, 2018–2020. Manila. 
4  World Travel and Tourism Council. 2018. Travel and Tourism Economic Impact 2018: China. London. 
5  World Tourism Organization. 2018. UNWTO Tourism Highlights, 2018 Edition. Madrid.

2 
5.  In terms of development, Qinghai lags the east-coast regions of the PRC, and the income 
inequality between its urban and rural population is significant.6 Among the major industries such 
as manufacturing, tourism is a potentially growing industry in Qinghai. Because of its unique 
geographic location, rich culture, and history, Qinghai has diverse natural and cultural assets. The 
provincial government defined tourism as the key strategic industry to be promoted because 
ecological protection is the province’s priority. Tourism also provides opportunities for rural 
villages to highlight their distinctive local cultures. However, tourism development in Qinghai is 
not mature and investments are not producing quality outcomes because the tourism industry 
lacks (i) value-adding products, (ii) regional cooperation, (iii) skilled human resources, (iv) an 
enabling environment for private tourism businesses, (v) an institutional mechanism, (vi) tourism 
promotion, and (vii) a healthy balance between the supply of tourism products and services and 
the increasing demand of tourists. 
 
6.  Qinghai’s challenges are that (i) its extensive land area, geographic features, and limited 
connectivity make it difficult for tourists to visit multiple locations during their stay in Qinghai, and 
also for scattered tourism spots, cities, and villages to form tourism clusters to enjoy economies 
of scale; (ii) the industrial chain of tourism and associated industries and facilities is not strongly 
formed, and mutual benefits or synergies are not fully utilized; (iii) Qinghai lacks strong pull factors 
for tourists despite its unique ecological and cultural characteristics and resources; (iv) the 
institutional setting for the provinces and regions outside of Qinghai to implement tourism plans 
is weak, making it difficult for Qinghai or other areas along the Silk Road to achieve regional or 
interprovincial implementation of tourism projects; and (v) Qinghai needs very careful tourism and 
rural development planning and implementation because the preservation of the ecology is the 
top priority for Qinghai.7  
 
7.  Since 2016, the Qinghai government has issued policies, directions, and opinions on 
accelerating holistic and strategic tourism development, rural village tourism, poverty alleviation 
and regional cooperation through tourism, which is in line with the national program of creating 
competitive  tourist  routes  and  products  with  Silk  Road  features.  Its  Tourism  Development 
Thirteenth  Five-Year  Plan,  2016–2020  gives  strategic  guidance  on  how  to  achieve  these 
objectives.8 In 2018, the Government of the PRC has launched the Strategic Plan for Rural 
Vitalization, 2018–2022; and Action Plan for Promoting Quality Improvement of Rural Tourism 
Development, 2018–2022 that emphasizes the importance of protecting and promoting local and 
rural culture and ecological characteristics in tourism development.9 Therefore, it becomes 
absolutely essential for Qinghai to conduct a detailed study and formulate a practical action plan 
to implement the plans and policies for sustainable tourism in Qinghai, and for the northwestern 
provinces and regions in the PRC to coordinate tourism development. 
 
                                                
6  By economic sector, Qinghai’s gross regional product ratios in 2016 were 8.6 (primary), 48.6 (secondary), and 
42.8 (tertiary). Despite the growth in the secondary economic sector, Qinghai’s per capita gross regional product was 
CNY44,348 in 2017—about one-third that of Beijing or Shanghai. Per capita disposable income of households in 
Qinghai is lower than the national average or about one-third that of Beijing or Shanghai. Within Qinghai, rural 
households' per capita disposable income is about one-third that of urban households. National Bureau of Statistics 
of the PRC. 2017. China Statistical Yearbook 2017. Beijing: China Statistics Press; Statistics Bureau of Qinghai 
Province. 2017. Qinghai Statistical Yearbook 2017. Beijing: China Statistics Press. 
7  Government of the PRC, State Council Information Office. 2018. Ecological Progress on the Qinghai–Tibet Plateau. 
Beijing. Foreign Languages Press Co. Ltd. 
8  Government of the PRC, Qinghai Provincial Government. 2016. Tourism Development Thirteenth Five-Year Plan, 
2016–2020. Xining (in Chinese).  
9  Government  of  the  PRC.  2018.  Strategy  Plan  for  Rural  Vitalization,  2018–2022.  Beijing  (in  Chinese); and 
Government of the PRC, National Development and Reform Commission. 2018. Action Plan for Promoting Quality 
Improvement of Rural Tourism Development, 2018–2022. Beijing (in Chinese).

3 
8.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  ADB’s  Strategy  2030  by  reducing  inequality  in  access  to 
opportunities  and  promoting  rural  development.  ADB’s  strategic  priorities  in  the  country 
partnership strategy, 2016–2020 for the PRC include supporting green and inclusive development 
and reducing poverty and inequality. ADB will assist the PRC government’s efforts in reducing 
poverty, particularly in the lesser-developed regions of the PRC (footnote 1). 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: (i) competitive tourist routes and products 
with Silk Road features created; and (ii) holistic tourism supporting local features and ecological 
protection promoted.10 The TA will have the following outcome: sustainable, inclusive, and 
regionally integrated tourism policies adopted.11 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  The TA team will provide knowledge support to the Qinghai government to formulate 
practical solutions (i) for sustainable regional tourism development, and (ii) to consult with tourism 
institutions in and outside of Qinghai for potential regional tourism cooperation in the future. The 
TA team will provide support through research, capacity development workshops and study tours, 
and policy and institutional advice. It will assist the evaluation of the existing tourism policies and 
provide inputs to the Qinghai Provincial Fourteenth Five-Year Plan, 2021–2025 and the Qinghai 
government’s tourism policy formulation. 
 
11.  Output 1: Integrated institutional mechanism for regional tourism development 
proposed.  The  TA  will  provide  a  forum  for  tourism-related  local  administration  officers, 
international and national experts, and local businesses to exchange ideas on institutional and 
implementation mechanism relating to (i) coordination between Qinghai local administrations and 
tourism destinations; and (ii) coordination between neighboring northwestern provinces and 
regions on tourism development. The TA team will support the organization of workshops and 
prepare recommendations for local governments to design a cooperation and implementation 
mechanism for sustainable regional tourism. Through this activity, Qinghai will explore the local 
and international inbound tourism market, integrate outbound and domestic tourism markets, 
strengthen tourism cooperation between PRC regions, discuss a development and marketing plan 
for inbound tourism, and promote exchanges between people who have common interests in 
cultural and ethnic background. 
 
12.  Output 2: Sustainable, competitive, and practical regional tourism development 
strategy for Qinghai proposed. The TA team will support the implementing agency and key 
local policy makers in deepening the understanding of and capacity for sustainable tourism 
development by (i) collecting and analyzing data on the current situation of Qinghai tourism, 
especially as regards regional cooperation and cultural aspects, and identifying bottlenecks and 
other problems; (ii) learning about national and international good practices and case studies of 
sustainable  and  regional  tourism  development;  and  (iii) preparing  policy  analysis  and 
recommendations covering (a) tourism product development and route planning; (b) tourism 
                                                
10 Government of the PRC, National Development and Reform Commission; Ministry of Foreign Affairs; and Ministry of 
Commerce. 2015. Vision and Actions on Jointly Building Silk Road Economic Belt and 21st-Century Maritime Silk 
Road; and Government of the PRC, State Council Information Office. 2018. Ecological Progress on the Qinghai–
Tibet Plateau. Beijing: Foreign Languages Press Co. Ltd. 
11 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
development  considering  cultural  similarities;  (c)  development  of  a  tourism  industry  chain; 
(d) marketing or branding strategy; and (e) ecological protection, cultural preservation, rural 
vitalization, and poverty alleviation. The TA team will deliver this output through research, surveys, 
study tours to domestic and international case study locations, and by preparing reports. As part 
of tourism marketing and branding, the TA team will consider innovative approaches of engaging 
with rural people and the use of information technologies.  
 
13.  Output 3: Tourism-related action plans with investment priority list prepared. Based 
on the research findings and recommendations, the TA team will formulate an action plan for each 
Qinghai  prefecture  and  a  list  of  potential  investments  for  future  consideration  by  local 
governments or local and international financiers. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, meeting facilities, data, information, printing, 
coordination and arrangement activities, part of interpretation costs, domestic study visit costs, 
knowledge dissemination, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The Urban and Social Sectors Division of ADB’s East Asia Department will administer the 
TA. The Qinghai Provincial Finance Department will be the executing agency responsible for 
providing guidance and support to all stakeholders during project implementation. The Qinghai 
Provincial Commission of Tourism Development will be the implementing agency responsible for 
working closely with consultants engaged under the TA and coordinate between stakeholders 
during TA implementation. 
 
16.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

Source: Asian Development Bank.

5 
17.  Consulting  services.  ADB  will  recruit  an  international  individual  consultant  and  a 
consulting firm consisting of national consultants. It will use the consultants’ qualification selection 
method for a consulting firm recruitment because the highly specialized assignment requires 
familiarity with Qinghai’s ecological and cultural features and the situation of tourism industries. 
ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from 
time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.12 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of the People’s Republic of China for Research on Qinghai’s Integration into Belt 
and Road Tourism, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                
12 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Integrated institutional mechanism for regional tourism development proposed 
1.1 Conduct a TA inception workshop to discuss the objectives and direction with key stakeholders, 
consultants, resource persons, and external peer reviewers in Q2 2019 
1.2 Draft integrated institutional mechanism for regional tourism development in Q2 2019–Q1 2020 
1.3 Conduct a TA consultative workshop to discuss the progress with key stakeholders, consultants, 
resource persons, and external peer reviewers in Q4 2019 
1.4 Conduct a TA consultative workshop to discuss the draft final report with the key stakeholders, 
consultants, resource persons, and external peer reviewers in Q1 2020 
1.5 Finalize the report and knowledge product in Q1–Q2 2020 
1.6 Conduct a TA final workshop for dissemination of outputs in Q3 2020 
 
2.  Sustainable, competitive, and practical regional tourism development strategy for Qinghai 
proposed 
2.1 Mobilize consultants by Q2 2019 
2.2 Conduct field surveys and research activities in Q2 2019–Q1 2020 
2.3 Conduct domestic and international study tours and submit study tour reports in Q3–Q4 2019 
2.4 Finalize the research reports and knowledge product in Q1–Q2 2020 
2.5 Disseminate the recommendation in the TA final workshop in Q3 2020 
 
3.  Tourism-related action plans with investment priority list prepared 
3.1 Draft action plans based on the tourism development recommendations in Q3 2019–Q1 2020 
3.2 Draft investment priority list based on the tourism development recommendations in Q3 2019–Q1 2020 
3.3 Disseminate the action plans and the investment priority list in the TA final workshop in Q3 2020
